timeline.symptom: Pain localizing to right lower quadrant

treatment_protocol: Start IV fluids and antibiotics → Confirm diagnosis via imaging → Proceed to appendectomy
epidemiology: Affects ~7% of the population. Most common in adolescents and young adults (10–30 years). Slight male predominance. Rare in infants and elderly.

treatment_protocol: Clinical diagnosis → Elective repair if reducible → Emergency surgery if strangulated
epidemiology: Lifetime risk is 27% in men and 3% in women. More common in older adults and premature infants. Higher prevalence in developing countries.

treatment_protocol: Ultrasound confirmation → Assess for complications → Elective surgery if symptomatic
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Hospital admission → IV antibiotics and fluids → Surgery within 72 hrs
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Resuscitation → Imaging → Emergency surgery with Graham patch or definitive repair
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Conservative management → Office procedures if persistent → Surgery for grade III/IV
epidemiology: Affects ~50% of adults over 50 years. Common during pregnancy. Higher prevalence in those with chronic constipation and prolonged straining.

emergency_markers: Visible chronic fissure with sentinel pile

treatment_protocol: Topical treatment + sitz baths → Surgery if refractory >6 weeks
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Incise and drain acute abscess → Elective wide excision for definitive cure
epidemiology: Primarily affects young adult males (15–35 years). More common in hairy individuals and those with sedentary jobs. Recurrence is common after surgical treatment.

treatment_protocol: Empiric antibiotics → Image-guided aspiration or surgical drainage
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Treat infection → Plan for elective excision using Sistrunk operation
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Monitor for 4–6 weeks → Drain if persistent or symptomatic
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Clinical confirmation → Urgent surgery due to high risk of strangulation
epidemiology: Accounts for <5% of all hernias. More common in women, especially older or multiparous women. High risk of strangulation.

timeline.symptom: Sudden severe epigastric pain radiating to back

definitive: Treat underlying cause (e.g. cholecystectomy if gallstones)

treatment_protocol: Supportive management → Monitor severity (Ranson/BISAP) → Surgery only if complications
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Surgery if symptomatic or persistent
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Conservative therapy → Ablative therapy or surgery for complications
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Prompt surgical drainage → Antibiotics if cellulitis or systemic signs
epidemiology: Most common in young adult males. Often results from infection of anal glands. Recurrence and fistula formation occur in up to 40% of cases.

treatment_protocol: Assess complexity → Choose between fistulotomy vs sphincter-preserving technique
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Elective excision if not infected → Drain first if acutely infected
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Surgical excision for symptomatic or enlarging lipomas
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Conservative for small, asymptomatic hernias → Elective repair for larger or symptomatic
epidemiology: Common in infants (especially preterm and African descent). Usually resolves by age 2–4. In adults, linked to obesity and pregnancy.

treatment_protocol: Medical management → Surgery for refractory or complicated cases
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Diagnosis via biopsy → Staging → Neoadjuvant therapy + Surgery if operable
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Confirm via manometry → Endoscopic/surgical management depending on risk
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Triple therapy for H. pylori → Endoscopic surveillance → Surgery if refractory or complicated
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Staging → Gastrectomy + lymphadenectomy → Adjuvant therapy based on histology
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Diagnosis via biopsy → Surgical resection → Adjuvant therapy based on risk stratification
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Radiological diagnosis → Appendectomy or colectomy depending on histology
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

timeline.symptom: Severe abdominal pain out of proportion to exam

treatment_protocol: High index of suspicion → CT angiography → Urgent surgical intervention if ischemia confirmed
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Attempt endoscopic detorsion → Elective or emergency surgery depending on viability
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Primary survey → FAST/CT → Surgery if unstable or findings suggestive of intra-abdominal injury
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Conservative → Surgery if persistent or symptomatic
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Grade 1–2: Conservative → Grade 3–4: Surgical options
epidemiology: Affects ~50% of adults over 50 years. Common during pregnancy. Higher prevalence in those with chronic constipation and prolonged straining.

treatment_protocol: Acute: medical → Chronic or non-healing: surgical
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

definitive: Excision with primary closure or healing by secondary intention

treatment_protocol: Drain abscess if present → Excision of sinus tract
epidemiology: Primarily affects young adult males (15–35 years). More common in hairy individuals and those with sedentary jobs. Recurrence is common after surgical treatment.

treatment_protocol: Determine etiology → Monitor or treat appropriately
epidemiology: Data on prevalence, age distribution, sex predilection, and regional patterns to be added.

treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Attempt non-operative reduction → Surgery if needed
epidemiology: Most common abdominal emergency in children under 2 years. Incidence ~1–4 per 1000 live births. Male predominance. Rare in adults.

treatment_protocol: Confirm via scan or surgery → Resection if symptomatic or complicated
epidemiology: Present in ~2% of the population. Male-to-female ratio ~2:1. Symptomatic in only 2–4% of cases, typically in children under 10 years.

treatment_protocol: Endoscopic removal → Surveillance depending on pathology
epidemiology: Prevalence increases with age—~30% in people over 50. Common in Western countries. Associated with dietary and genetic factors.

timeline.symptom: Intermittent abdominal pain (usually left lower quadrant)

definitive: Colectomy if recurrent bleeding or complications

treatment_protocol: Manage conservatively → Surgery if recurrent or complicated
epidemiology: Affects ~50% of people over 60 years in developed countries. Low-fiber diets increase risk. Often asymptomatic.

definitive: Surgical resection if complicated or recurrent

treatment_protocol: Medical management initially → Surgery for complications or recurrence
epidemiology: Occurs in 10–25% of patients with diverticulosis. More frequent in older adults. Rising incidence in younger populations with Western diets.

treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Imaging → Emergency surgery
epidemiology: Incidence varies by cause. Peptic ulcer is the leading cause worldwide. Most common in adults aged 40–60. Higher rates in developing countries due to delayed diagnosis.

treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Imaging → Enterolithotomy ± delayed cholecystectomy
epidemiology: Rare complication of cholelithiasis (~0.3–0.5%). Most common in elderly women (>70 years). Accounts for <5% of all mechanical bowel obstructions.

treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Surgery within 72 hours for best outcome
epidemiology: Affects ~10–15% of individuals with gallstones. More common in women, especially between ages 30–60. Risk increases with obesity, pregnancy, and rapid weight loss.

treatment_protocol: Stabilize → ERCP for decompression → Elective cholecystectomy
epidemiology: Incidence rising due to increased use of ERCP. More common in individuals over 50. Slight male predominance. Associated with choledocholithiasis and biliary strictures.

definitive: Treat underlying cause (ERCP for gallstones, alcohol cessation)

treatment_protocol: Conservative management → Intervention if complications arise
epidemiology: Incidence ranges from 4.9 to 35 per 100,000 annually. Gallstones and alcohol are most common causes. Affects adults 30–60 years. Male predominance in alcoholic cases.
Rare; seen in immunocompromised, trauma, or infective endocarditis patients.
treatment_protocol: Suspect in febrile LUQ pain → imaging → antibiotics ± drainage/splenectomy

epidemiology: Affects ~2% of population, symptomatic in <10%. More common in males.

definitive: Surgical resection (diverticulectomy or segmental bowel resection)

treatment_protocol: Imaging confirmation → surgical removal

epidemiology: Most common in adolescents (12–18 years); true emergency.
treatment_protocol: Clinical suspicion → emergency surgery within 6 hrs

epidemiology: Rare; associated with FAP (Gardner syndrome).

definitive: Imatinib or radiotherapy for unresectable lesions

treatment_protocol: Image & biopsy → resect if symptomatic or enlarging

epidemiology: One of the most lethal cancers. Peak incidence in 60–80 years.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → stage → surgery if resectable

epidemiology: Common in endemic regions; can affect peritoneum, lymph nodes, bowel. High incidence in immunocompromised patients.
treatment_protocol: Confirm via fluid/biopsy → ATT → surgery if obstruction or perforation

epidemiology: Common after acid reflux, caustic ingestion, or post-radiation.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with imaging/endoscopy → dilation → consider surgery

epidemiology: Rare idiopathic inflammatory condition affecting mesentery; most cases middle-aged to elderly men.
treatment_protocol: Radiological diagnosis → medical therapy → surgery if needed

epidemiology: Rare but life-threatening; higher risk with ectopic gastric tissue or inflammation.
treatment_protocol: Resuscitate → imaging/laparoscopy → surgery

epidemiology: Often due to trauma, anticoagulation, or vigorous coughing; seen in elderly.
treatment_protocol: Clinical/imaging confirmation → conservative or surgical based on severity
